keyTakeAways: South Korean police are seeking warrants for 58 repatriated nationals from Cambodia accused of involvement in 'pig butchering' scams.
The scams involve luring victims into fake romantic relationships and persuading them to invest in fraudulent cryptocurrency platforms, a practice known as 'pig butchering'.
Approximately 1,000 South Korean citizens are believed to be working in Cambodian scam centres under coercive conditions, often after being trafficked through false job offers.
The repatriations were prompted by public outrage following the August 2025 killing of a South Korean college student, who was found dead in a pick-up truck after being kidnapped and tortured.
South Korea sent a delegation to Cambodia, including police and intelligence agents, to discuss the issue, leading to travel bans in certain Cambodian regions.
The United States and the United Kingdom have imposed sweeping sanctions on the Prince Group, a Cambodia-based crime network operating scam centres across the region.
Japan has also responded by arresting three individuals linked to Cambodia-based scams, showing regional cooperation in combating cyber fraud and human trafficking.
The growth of scam centres in Cambodia has been exacerbated since the pandemic, as Chinese-owned casinos and hotels shifted to illicit operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean police are seeking warrants for 58 of 64 repatriated nationals from Cambodia, who are accused of involvement in 'pig butchering' scams—fraudulent operations involving fake romantic relationships and cryptocurrency investments. These scams, reportedly targeting victims globally, have led to the trafficking of South Korean citizens through false job offers, with approximately 1,000 believed to be currently operating in Cambodian scam centres. The repatriations follow public outrage after the August 2025 killing of a South Korean college student, who was found dead after being kidnapped and tortured. South Korea has responded by sending a diplomatic and law enforcement delegation to Cambodia, banning travel to certain areas, and intensifying investigations. Internationally, the US and UK have imposed sanctions on the Prince Group, a Cambodia-based crime network running scam centres, while Japan has arrested individuals linked to similar operations, showing a coordinated regional response to this growing cybercrime and human trafficking crisis.
title: South Korea police seek warrants for 58 repatriated scam centre suspects
